The various levels of coordination are exemplified in the following sections.
In general, coordination is between like categories. For sentence-level coordination, this means that two declarative sentences may be conjoined, as in:
p.langData: John went to the office this morning and he just got back
p.content: and
p.langData: Either I will come to the party or I will send my sister
p.content: , or two questions, as in:
p.langData: When did the mail come and where is my package?

, one of the conjuncts must be negative, as in:

Finally, adjectives or adjective phrases can usually be coordinated, both when they are modifying a noun, as in:
p.langData: The black and white dog belongs to my son
My sister wants a bright red or light blue candle
p.content: and
p.langData: That looks like an awfully painful and very dangerous sore on your leg
p.content: , and when they are acting as the predicate adjective in a copular sentence, as in:
p.langData: The sore on your leg is awfully painful and very dangerous
p.content: and

Lists consist of three or more items that are conjoined to form a single nominal phrase. The initial items are normally separated by commas and there is an overt conjunction before the final item in the list, though there are different possibilities. Some English examples of nominal phrases consisting of lists are:
p.langData: [John, Bill, Sue and Mary]
[John, Bill, Sue and/or Mary]
[John and Bill or Sue and Mary]
p.content: and
p.langData: [a cat, two dogs and a chicken but not a monkey]

Appositives also form a single nominal phrase. Appositives normally consist of a name followed by a comma and then a description also followed by a comma, or the order may be reversed. Some English examples include:
p.langData: [George Washington, the first President of the United States,]
p.content: and
p.langData: [My brother, James,]

This section considers comparatives which have two sentences surrounding the comparative word, though the second sentence may be missing the adjective. Shorter comparatives, which are a subtype of copular sentences, were covered in section

. Like the shorter comparatives, these compare the qualities or actions of the subjects of the sentences and may have a copular verb or a perception verb or an action verb, along with an adjective that is modified by a degree word or affix. Some English examples are :
p.langData: John is more handsome than Bill is
Sue runs much faster than Mary can run
David appears lots taller than Michael does
Mary looks prettier than Julie looks
p.content: and
p.langData: John seems more certain of his answers than Sue seems

p.content: Some languages do not allow any part of the second sentence to be omitted and instead always have two full sentences being compared. Also, languages which do not have a separate comparative word meaning
for the shorter comparative constructions will simply have the two sentence parts following one another in this construction.
